subject: RE: [junit] assertEquals error message
msgSnippet: Hi Jim, It took me a while to figure out what was going on here.  I think what is happening is that assert equals uses ... for equal parts of the expected
messageBody:
Hi Jim,

It took me a while to figure out what was going on here. I think what
is happening is that assert equals uses "..." for equal parts of the
expected and actual values. So in your example, "<... ...> but was
<......>" means that there was not a space where it expected one to be.


assertEquals("foobar", "abc", "abc123") would print:
Foobar expected: <...> but was <...123>

If you don't like this behavior you can always implement your own
version of assertEquals.

Hope this helps,
Kris

>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Jim Shore [mailto:jshore@...]
> Sent: Monday, October 13, 2003 5:45 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>
> I'm trying to find the right place to ask for a change to
> JUnit. I hope
> this is it. If not, please tell me where to go. :)
>
> In the current version of JUnit, assertEquals displays an
> edited message
> when it fails. This is very frustrating as it makes it
> difficult for me
> to see the source of my errors.
>
> For example, the below test displays this error:
>
> The test:
>
> public void testArrggghhh() {
> assertEquals("foobar", "foo bar", "foobar");
> }
>
> Displays: "foobar expected: <... ...> but was <......>"
>
> This error message is useless for me. I work around it, of
> course, but
> it's making me go a lot slower. I would like to see this
> feature turned
> off or made more sophisticated by the introduction of more surrounding
> context (say, at least ten characters on each side). Any plans to fix
> it?
>
> Jim
>
>
>
